item.title: Talks on Syrian Conflict Resume in Geneva
item.description: Government and opposition delegations returned for a second round of peace negotiations after the first round ended 10 days ago with little progress.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Louay Safi, a spokesman for Syria’s main opposition group, at a press briefing in Geneva on Monday.

item.title: Nepal Ends Long Stalemate in Picking Prime Minister
item.description: Parliament on Monday elected Sushil Koirala, a longtime democratic activist and a member of one of Nepal’s most storied political families.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Sushil Koirala, a member of one of Nepal's most storied political families, was elected by Parliament as the country’s new prime minister.

item.title: The Lede: Turkey Deports Journalist for Criticizing Government on Twitter
item.description: Turkey deported an Azerbaijani journalist on Friday for “posting tweets against high-level state officials,” according to an Interior Ministry order obtained by his newspaper, the English-language daily Today’s Zaman.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Suicide Bomb Instructor Accidentally Kills Iraqi Pupils
item.description: Twenty-two militants attending a suicide bombing training were killed when a commander mistakenly used an armed belt during a demonstration.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Suicide Bomber Attacks NATO Convoy in Afghanistan
item.description: Officials said two NATO contractors were killed in the attack on the convoy near Kabul’s main prison.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and HARIS KAKAR
item.media:description: American troops inspect the site of a suicide attack near Kabul’s main prison on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: State Television Reveals: Sin in China’s “Sin City”
item.description: The online reaction to a state media report on prostitution in the southern city of Dongguan was, roughly: This is news?
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: An alleged sex worker covering her face after being detained by the police at an entertainment center in Dongguan.

item.title: DealBook: Chinese Official Made Job Plea to JPMorgan Chase Chief
item.description: A top Chinese regulator directly asked Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief executive, for a “favor” to hire a young job applicant, a confidential email shows. The applicant, a family friend of the regulator, now works at JPMorgan.
item.dc:creator: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and BEN PROTESS
item.media:description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive and chairman of JPMorgan Chase, at a Senate panel in 2012.

item.title: India Ink: Four Foreign Tourists Arrested After Knife Attack in Goa
item.description: Two Russians and two Egyptians are in custody after an altercation at a beach shack that left a waiter with a slashed face.
item.dc:creator: By SHARON FERNANDES

item.title: Swiss Immigration Vote Raises Alarm Across Europe
item.description: Some leaders said a referendum limiting the number of foreigners allowed to live and work in Switzerland is a retreat from European integration.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: European Union foreign ministers met in Brussels on Monday to discuss the Swiss immigration vote and the political crisis in Ukraine.

item.title: India Ink: Autopsy of Arunachal Pradesh Student Confirms Assault Caused Death, Uncle Says
item.description: Before he died, Nido Tania told his father that he had been beaten by two shopkeepers who are accused of using an ethnic slur against him.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting the death of Nido Tania, a student from Arunachal Pradesh, in New Delhi on Feb. 2.

item.title: India Ink: A Farewell to the Maruti 800, Humble King of India’s Roads
item.description: The tough, no-frills hatchback, which has ceased production after more than 30 years, has earned the affection of legions of fans, who include the author.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: The author with his beloved Maruti 800 in front of Rashtrapati Bhavan, residence of India's President, in New Delhi, on Monday.

item.title: Letter from Europe: Awaiting Russia’s Next Move in Ukraine
item.description: Western diplomats worry over the possibility of more aggressive moves by Russia once the Sochi Games are over.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia shook hands with his Ukrainian counterpart, Viktor F. Yanukovych, before an official reception in Sochi on Friday.

item.title: Swiss Voters Narrowly Approve Curbs on Immigration
item.description: Voters backed measures to reintroduce restrictions on the number of foreigners allowed to live and work in the country, a move that could have implications for the nation’s ties with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Voters waited in Zurich on Sunday to cast their ballots on proposals to limit the number of foreigners allowed to live and work in Switzerland.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Nude Sunbathers Ordered to Cover Up
item.description: The police in Sanya, a seaside city in the country’s far south, are warning old men not to tan naked on a beach there.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Sunbathers at a beach in Sanya, Hainan Province, watch as government officials post a notice on the ban on public nudity.

item.title: Turkey Struggles to Protect Its Lira
item.description: The frenzy of currency traders at Istanbul’s Grand Bazaar is a demonstration of how the value of Turkey’s money is determined largely by events beyond the country’s control.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:credit: Guy Martin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Traders bartering in a Grand Bazaar alley in Istanbul. Since May, the lira has lost a third of its value against the dollar, and the consequences of a further decline would be serious.

item.title: North Korea Balks Again at Bid to Free American
item.description: An invitation for a special envoy to visit on behalf of Kenneth Bae, a Christian missionary serving a 15-year sentence, was rescinded for a second time.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Kenneth Bae is serving a 15-year sentence in North Korea.

item.title: Gerd Albrecht, German Conductor and Lightning Rod, Is Dead at 78
item.description: Mr. Albrecht, a German, had a volatile run as the first non-Czech to lead the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Gerd Albrecht in 1996. For him, music and politics mixed.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Despite Frigid Relations, Chinese Relics Coming Home From Norway
item.description: Seven marble columns from the Old Summer Palace in Beijing, acquired more than a century ago by a former Norwegian cavalry officer, are set to return home this fall under an agreement between a Norwegian museum and a Chinese businessman.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:credit: Dag Fosse/KODE Art Museums of Bergen
item.media:description: Seven marble columns from the Old Summer Palace in Beijing at the KODE Art Museums in Bergen, Norway. Under an agreement with a Chinese property developer, they will be returned to China this autumn.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Television War on Japan
item.description: Not much has changed over the years: Enemy Japanese soldiers still run amok on Chinese screens, the Chinese novelist and blogger Murong Xuecun writes in an op-ed column.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: 8 Killed in Attack on Sufi Gathering
item.description: Gunmen threw grenades at a Sufi Islamic religious gathering on Sunday in the port city of Karachi and then opened fire on the people assembled to offer prayers, killing eight, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Tunisia Arrests Assassination Suspect
item.description: Tunisia’s government said Sunday that a suspect in the July 25 assassination of an opposition politician was among four men arrested in an overnight counterterrorism raid.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Troops Halt Attack In Central Africa
item.description: The Rwandan peacekeepers aimed to halt an attack on Muslims, shooting dead a member of a crowd that had killed two people in Bangui, a spokesman said.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sochi Got the Gold. Bypassed Village Got Dust.
item.description: Every Olympics has its local casualties, and some Russian towns have fared better than others. Akhshtyr, a barren mountain village near Sochi, has fared very badly indeed.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A truck in the garden of a house. Many of the villagers do not have cars; for as long as they can remember, they happily came and went across the river on foot.

item.title: Members of Pussy Riot Visit Residents at Halfway House
item.description: Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova said that perhaps the best part of a trip to New York was interacting with inmates and hearing from criminal justice experts.
item.dc:creator: By MELENA RYZIK
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova of Pussy Riot with Jacqueline Moore and George Washington.

item.title: Tokyo Rejects Candidate Who Stressed Nuclear Halt
item.description: In the governor’s race, voters chose a former health minister focused on local concerns over a former prime minister who campaigned on putting an end to atomically generated electricity.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
